alternatives.transcript: mister palmer is a sixty two year old male that presented us today with a chief complaint of fatigue and palpitations that have been going on for the last two weeks as far as his history goes the only additional thing is that he's also been experiencing experiencing near syncope with the with the palpitations and fatigue he says that this is this only occurs as he's performing activity like his his walks that he takes every day it's it's only past medical history that's pertinent is a history of hypertension however he does have a history of sudden death in the family his mother died at forty of unknown causes dad died of an mi at fifty nine only medication he's taking is ten milligrams of lisinopropia daily no allergies and no substance use he does drink one cup of coffee a day in addition to that his as far as his activity it's it's great he said that he hikes almost three to four miles daily with a group of friends and this this issue has been keeping him from doing that as far as physical exam goes he did not have any jvd or peripheral edema but he did have a systolic murmur with s four and a laterally displaced pmi overall this patient's major presenting problem is fatigue my differential diagnosis included concentric left ventricular hypertrophy sarcoidosis myocarditis and familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy i think given this patient's family history and his his immediate past medical history as well as the tests that we ordered the echo the ekg the chest x-ray and the the lab work are all are all in line with with hopam being the leading diagnosis as far as a plan for this patient i think that we should start them on desopiramide discontinue lisinopril and consult interventional cardiology for defibrillator placement and cardiothoracic surgery for either myectomy or a septomyectomy or an alcohol ablation
